title: 106_hr4536
content: Title X of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 is amended to include a new section called "Physical Education for Progress Act." This section aims to provide grants and contracts to local educational agencies to enhance physical education programs for students from kindergarten to 12th grade. "Congress finds that physical education is essential for children's development, improving their health, self-esteem, relationships, behavior, and independence." Physical education is crucial for children's development, improving their health, self-esteem, relationships, behavior, and independence. Participation in high-quality physical education programs can lead to better health and fitness in children. The prevalence of obesity among children in the United States is linked to low levels of physical activity. Physical education programs promote health and fitness, reducing the risk of obesity-related diseases and premature deaths. Physically fit adults have lower risks of heart attacks and stroke. Overweight rates among young people have doubled in the past 30 years, with inactivity and poor diet contributing to obesity prevalence. Obesity-related diseases cost the US economy over $100 billion annually. Obesity-related diseases cost the US economy over $100 billion annually. Inactivity and poor diet cause at least 300,000 deaths a year. Physically fit adults have reduced risk factors for heart attacks and stroke. Children are not as active as they should be, with fewer than 1 in 4 getting 20 minutes of vigorous activity daily. Surgeon General's 1996 Report and CDC recommend daily physical education for all students. Children are not as active as they should be, with fewer than 1 in 4 getting 20 minutes of vigorous activity daily. The Surgeon General's 1996 Report and CDC recommend daily physical education for all students from kindergarten to grade 12. Twelve years after Congress passed a resolution encouraging high-quality daily physical education. Twelve years after Congress passed a resolution encouraging high-quality daily physical education for all students from kindergarten to grade 12, little progress has been made. Every student in the nation's schools should have the opportunity to participate in quality physical education. Despite a resolution urging agencies to provide daily physical education programs for all students from kindergarten to grade 12, little progress has been made. It is essential for students to have the opportunity to participate in quality physical education to develop health-related fitness and cognitive understanding about physical activity for adopting healthy lifestyles. The role of quality physical education programs is to develop health-related fitness, physical competence, and cognitive understanding about physical activity for all students to adopt healthy and active lifestyles. Every student should have the opportunity to achieve the goals set by Healthy People 2000 and Healthy People 2010. "SEC. 10999D. PROGRAM AUTHORIZED." The Secretary can award grants to local educational agencies for physical education programs for K-12 students, including equipment, curriculum development, and teacher training. "SEC. 10999E. APPLICATIONS; PROGRAM REQUIREMENTS." Each local educational agency must submit an application to the Secretary outlining a plan to enhance physical education programs in schools to meet national goals and state standards. State standards for physical education include goals such as fitness education, motor skills instruction, and activities to enhance physical, mental, and social development. The state standards for physical education focus on fitness education, motor skills instruction, cognitive concepts about physical fitness, and developing positive social skills through physical activity. The state standards for physical education emphasize fitness education, motor skills, cognitive concepts about physical fitness, social skills development through physical activity, and instruction in healthy eating habits and nutrition. Teachers of physical education should receive professional development opportunities to stay updated on research and trends in the field. Teachers of physical education should receive professional development opportunities to stay updated on research, issues, and trends in the field. Extracurricular activities like team sports and ROTC programs are not considered part of the assisted physical education curriculum. The Secretary ensures equitable distribution of grants and contracts between urban and rural local educational agencies, as well as between agencies serving large and small student populations. Private school and home-schooled students are also included in the provisions. The Secretary ensures equitable distribution of grants and contracts between urban and rural local educational agencies, as well as between agencies serving large and small student populations. Private school and home-schooled students can participate in activities funded under this part. An application for funds under this part may include home-schooled and private school children and teachers in funded activities. A report is required for continued funding. "An annual report is required for continued funding of multiyear grants or contracts under this part. The report must describe activities conducted and show progress towards goals or meeting State standards for physical education." "Secretary to report to Congress by June 1, 2003 on programs assisted under this part, their success in improving physical fitness, and recommendations for program continuation and improvement. Administrative costs limited to 5% of grant funds. Federal share must supplement, not supplant." Federal share under this part may not exceed 90% of total project cost in the first year and 75% in subsequent years. Funds must supplement, not supplant other available federal, state, and local funds for physical education activities. Authorization of appropriations is also included. Authorization of appropriations for fiscal years 2000 to 2004 totaling $30,000,000, $70,000,000, and $100,000,000 respectively, to support physical education activities.
